column4: only, if autorun is active. Use TweakUI or something similar to switch it off, then you can mount the drive and scan for viruses safely.
DasEi: i took all necessary measures to disable autorun (including the vista patch), but i still don't trust that after the technical articles i've seen

oh, vista... sorry, anything above XP doesnt exist in my personal reality... i don't know, how it is in vista. Should be the same, i think. You could just remove any executeable from the drive using a live cd.
yes, i had hoped to do that -- but i'm doing this from hundreds of miles away, and the man i'm helping has no transportation and no extra blank media
i had him acquire one blank disc initially, and he cannot boot it for some reason (bad media, or lousy dvd reader)
does he need to keep the software from the infected drive? Another issue would be worms (vbscript viruses, in docs)
I plan on destroying any software I find on the drive as soon as we get him in a safe environment
problems getting his new install online?
you said, he had a freshly installed sys. Windows?
yes, he recovered via the angel partition that laptops have
i'd try to remote login to the machine, let the user connect the infected drive and hope, the sys wont get infected again. He could wipe the sys off again.
appreciate that link, i did the registry fix as well as the WU patch, but given the risk involved i'll play it safe
alright... i know your pain. I hope, you will survive it without permanent brain damage.

esp. when said person has no transportation
as i said, i know this kind of situation. Good hunting!
